occurrences.line_text: To fly his stepdames loues outrageous,
To stay the steppe, ere forced to retrate.
Then stepped forth the goodly royall Mayd,
Of what might hap. Eftsoone there stepped forth
Mongst men of worth, I to her stepped neare,
He stepped forth with courage bold and great,
Then to him stepping, from his arme did reach
Stoutly forth stepping on the further shore,
But Satyrane forth stepping, did them stay
Vnder his stroke he to him stepping neare,
Who to them stepping did them soone diuide,
But to him stepping, such a stroke him lent,
There Coridon forth stepping openly,
Into whose stead faire falshood steps,
To weet the cause, his weake steps gouerning,
Then hunt the steps of pure vnspotted Maid:
With sturdie steps came stalking in his sight,
And left to losse: his stalking steps are stayde
And staggering steps, to weet, what suddein stowre
That on a staffe his feeble steps did frame,
Wont on a staffe his feeble steps to stay,
That hither turnes his steps. So few there bee,
They numberd euen steps and equall pace:
Wherein his weaker wandring steps to guide,
Where seeing Mercie, that his steps vp bare,
Whose staggering steps thy steady hand doth lead,
That with a staffe his feeble steps did stire,
Who taught his trampling steed with equall steps to tread.
And suffred not in wrath his hastie steps to stray.
Which to attend, a while their forward steps they stay.
Pursew her steps, through wild vnknowen wood;
But on a staffe her feeble steps did stay;
Ascending by ten steps of Alablaster wrought.
To which her steps directly she did frame.
His steed eke seem'd t'apply his steps to his intent.
Eftsoones her steps she thereunto applyde,
But forward with bold steps into the next roome went.
His feeble steps, which shrunke, when hard theron he lay.
And those two villeins, which her steps vpstayd,
With stately steps, and fearelesse countenance,
With easie steps so soft as foot could stryde.
Caught hold on me, and thought my steps to stay,
Might not my steps withhold, but that forthright
Then gan he make him tread his steps anew,
To tempt such steps, where footing was so ill:
The waies, through which my weary steps I guyde,
To which he meant his weary steps to guyde,
With stayed steps, and graue beseeming grace:
Well did he tract his steps, as he did ryde,
Trompart forth stept, to stay the mortall chaunce,
The which with monstrous stalke behind him stept,
Sternly stept forth, and raught away his speare,
Stept Braggadochio forth, and as his thrall
Which when that Squire beheld, he to them stept,
Eftsoones the Prince to him full nimbly stept,
Said then the Boteman, Palmer stere aright,
To stere the boate towards that dolefull Mayd,
The whiles that loue it steres, and fortune rowes;
For trumpets sterne to chaunge mine Oaten reeds,
Tho wrapping vp her wrethed sterne arownd,
His looke was sterne, and seemed still to threat
And stared sterne on all, that him beheld,
Ambitious Sylla, and sterne Marius,
(A lesson hard) and make the Libbard sterne
With staring countenance sterne, as one astownd,
And scared nations doest with horrour sterne astownd.
But gan his sturdie sterne about to weld,
But yet so sterne and terrible in sight,
Sterne melancholy did his courage pas,
And fiercely vnto battell sterne themselues prepar'd.
But chaufd and fom'd, with courage fierce and sterne,
And count'naunce sterne vpstanding, gan to grind
Sterne was his looke, and full of stomacke vaine,
But with sterne lookes, and stomachous disdaine,
Sterne was their looke, like wild amazed steares,
Stout Ferrex and sterne Porrex him in prison threw.
In their sterne brests, on him which late did driue
And with sterne horrour backward gan to start:
Yet therewith sore enrag'd, with sterne regard
He looked round about with sterne disdaine;
Emongst them was sterne Strife, and Anger stout,
Thereat Sir Blandamour with countenance sterne,
And looking sterne, still ouer him did stand,
And haue the sterne remembrance wypt away
With one sterne looke so daunted, that no ioy
To weet, sterne Druon, and lewd Claribell,
Now with faire speches, now with threatnings sterne,
Who with sterne countenance and indignant pride
But sayd, that he was obstinate and sterne,
Restraines those sterne behests, and cruell doomes of his.
Yet could it not sterne Artegall retaine,
From whose sterne presence they diffused ran,
His face was vgly, and his countenance sterne,
And with sterne count'naunce thus vnto him spake.
But put away proud looke, and vsage sterne,
Betwixt you two began this strife and sterne vprore.
Seeing his face so louely sterne and coy,
That he should be so sterne to stranger wight:
For he was sterne, and terrible by nature,
And with sterne eye-browes stared at him oft,
And sternely bad him other businesse plie,
Him sternely grypt, and haling to and fro,
And strooke at him so sternely, that he made
The knight approching, sternely her bespake;
The Boaster at him sternely bent his browe,
But that in stead therof, she sternely bade
She could it sternely draw, that all the world dismayde.
He sternely marcht before the Castle gate,
And sternely him beheld with grim and ghastly looke.
But Talus sternely did vpon them set,
But still the tyrant sternely at him layd,
Into his hart, and had so sternely wroke
And sternely with strong hand it from his handling kept.
Sternely did bid him quickely thence auaunt,
Rent by the root; which he so sternely shooke,
With which so sternely he the monster strooke,
Sternely he turnd againe, when he him strooke
Sometimes estranging him in sterner wise,
Tempred with sternesse and stout maiestie,
And sternly lookes at him, who not a pin
Sternly stept forth, and raught away his speare,
And sternly gan repine at his beheast;
Which when the other heard, she sternly frownd
That sonnes of men amazd their sternnesse to behold.
Mixed with manly sternnesse did appeare
Durst not the sternnesse of his looke abide,
The whiles he steru'd with hunger and with drouth
Are meet, the which doe men in bale to sterue,
Released her, that else was like to sterue,
For life it is to her, when others sterue
As burning Aetna from his boyling stew
For Steward was excessiue Gluttonie,
As Guardian and Steward of the rest:
He Steward was hight Diet; rype of age,
As him the Steward bad. They both attone
Faire Sthenoboea, that her selfe did choke
Or free his feet, that in the myre sticke fast?
And in the rest his readie speare did sticke;
In whose white alabaster brest did sticke
But byting deepe therein did sticke so fast,
Of which in me yet stickes the mortall sting,
A little cottage, built of stickes and reedes
The other halfe behind yet sticking fast,
Long here and there, and round about doth stie,
Vpstaring stiffe, dismayd with vncouth dread;
Wherewith the stiffe beame quaked, as affrayd,
And with stiffe force shaking his mortall launce,
A sturdy villein, striding stiffe and bold,
And though they both stood stiffe, yet could not both withstond.
Staring with hollow eyes, and stiffe vpstanding heares.
With his stiffe oares did brush the sea so strong,
And her faire locks vp stared stiffe on end,
To moderate stiffe minds, disposd to striue:
For he was strong and mightily stiffe pight,
In his strong armes he stiffely him embraste,
With that he stiffely shooke his steelehead dart:
But the more strong and stiffely that he ran,
Whiles th'one did row, and th'other stifly steare;
It fortuned, whilest thus she stifly stroue,
And with long locks vp-standing, stifly stared
With all the strength and stifnesse that he can.
Through such her stubborne stifnesse, and hard hart,
That neuer thoght one thing, but doubly stil was guided.
By which he stil them holds, & keepes with strong effort.
For stil when fit occasion did betyde,
Which softly stild, and kissing them atweene,
Ne can be stild for all his nurses might,
The argument of mine afflicted stile:
And with faire countenance and flattring stile,
Yet she still followed her former stile,
And crownd his coward crest with knightly stile;
To feed her humour with his pleasing stile,
And reach into the house, that beares the stile
Your honours stile, that is your warlike shield.
The antique rolles, which there lye hidden still,
And Poets sage, the Firre that weepeth still,
At last resoluing forward still to fare,
But still did follow one vnto the end,
Doth euer wash, and Cynthia still doth steepe
As still are wont t'annoy the walled towne,
Still flying from his thoughts and gealous feare;
Still dreading death, when she had marked long,
Still when she slept, he kept both watch and ward,
Still seeking him, that from her still did flie,
Still seeking him, that from her still did flie,
And still amidst her rayling, she did pray,
As you to leaue, that haue me loued still,
His looke was sterne, and seemed still to threat
He answered nought, but in a traunce still lay,
For on a sandie hill, that still did flit,
For still to all the gates stood open wide,
For to the highest she did still aspyre,
And in his hand his Portesse still he bare,
Still drownd in sleepe, and most of his dayes ded;
Still as he rode, he somewhat still did eat,
Still as he rode, he somewhat still did eat,
But both from backe and belly still did spare,
Vpon a rauenous wolfe, and still did chaw
Still as he rode, he gnasht his teeth, to see
And on his dagger still his hand he held,
So oft as Slowth still in the mire did stand.
Showting for ioy, and still before their way
Still did he wake, and still did watch for dawning light.
Still did he wake, and still did watch for dawning light.
To salue his hurts, that yet still freshly bled.
But still twixt feare and hope amazd does sit,
And seeke her spouse, that from her still does fly,
Yet goodly court he made still to his Dame,
And all his sences stound, that still he lay full low.
That famous hard atchieuements still pursew,
But all still shronke, and still he greater grew:
But all still shronke, and still he greater grew:
Which still she bore, replete with magick artes;
But he could not them vse, but kept them still in store.
So backward still was turnd his wrincled face,
Whose aunswere bad me still assured bee,
Which still wex old in woe, whiles woe still wexeth new.
Which still wex old in woe, whiles woe still wexeth new.
Yet still he stroue to cloke his inward bale,
Still as he fled, his eye was backward cast,
As if his feare still followed him behind;
That still for carrion carcases doth craue:
That holds the world in his still chaunging state,
Not purg'd nor heald, behind remained still,
Amendment readie still at hand did wayt,
The rest was all in yellow robes arayed still.
Whom still she fed, whiles they were weake & young,
But thrust them forth still, as they wexed old:
Which still before him she remou'd away,
The grace of God he layd vp still in store,
Who him awaited still with pensiue mind.
And all the heauens stood still amazed with his threat.
Out of his stinking gorge forth steemed still,
The steely head stucke fast still in his flesh,
But when he saw them come, he did them still forsake.
But praying still did wake, and waking did lament.
And marueiles at himselfe, still as he flies:
But hong still on the shield, as it at first was pight.
And daintie deare, which on the ground still fell,
That still he sate long time astonished
Still as he went, he craftie stales did lay
That he descride, and shonned still his slight:
For to all good he enimy was still.
Tho when as still he saw him towards pace,
With his blacke Palmer, that him guided still.
Still he him guided ouer dale and hill,
Of which he honour still away did beare,
For all his washing cleaner. Still he stroue,
Yet still the litle hands were bloudie seene;
But let them still be bloudy, as befell,
Still did they striue, and dayly disagree;
But still when Guyon came to part their fight,
Still stroue their stubborne rages to reuoke,
Full of disport, still laughing, loosely light,
Yet still he sat, and inly did him selfe torment.
Yet feare them followes still, where so they beene,
And to be easd of that base burden still did erne.
Still cald vpon to kill him in the place.
But still prouokt her sonne to wreake her wrong;
But nathelesse he did her still torment,
Yet his great yron teeth he still did grind,
Long I her seru'd, and found her faithfull still,
Their fell contention still increased more,
Thus in still waues of deepe delight to wade,
But the Blacke Palmer suffred still to stond,
Yet she still followed her former stile,
Wherewith astonisht, still he stood, as senselesse stone.
Still as he stood, faire PhÃ¦dria, that beheld
Still solemne sad, or still disdainfull coy,
Still solemne sad, or still disdainfull coy,
Backe to the strond retyrd, and there still stayd,
Yet still he bet the water, and the billowes dasht.
For still he traueild through wide wastfull ground,
To trouble my still seate, and heapes of pretious pelfe.
And trembling Feare still to and fro did fly,
Should be his pray. And therefore still on hye
Yet gaped still, as coueting to drinke
Woxe sore affraid, and standing still a space,
The trespasse still doth liue, albe the person die.
Nought could he hurt, but still at ward did ly:
Long trembling still he stood: at last thus sayd;
Still waites for death with dread and trembling aw;
Still open to their friends, and closed to their foes.
And were enraunged ready, still for fight.
Which he recorded still, as they did pas,
A litle boy did on him still attend,
But each his paines to others profit still employd.
Still as the greedy knight nigh to him drew,
But that lame Hag, still as abroad he strew
That whiles he marueild still, did still him paine:
That whiles he marueild still, did still him paine:
Whom still he marked freshly to arize
Ne ought saue perill, still as he did pas:
Which still sate waiting on that wastfull clift,
Like to a restlesse wheele, still running round,
Where as those Mermayds dwelt: it was a still
On th'other side an high rocke toured still,
But th'vpper halfe their hew retained still,
The ruefull Strich, still waiting on the bere,
Lookt on them louely, still in stedfast state,
That still it breathed forth sweet spirit & holesome smell.
But passed forth, and lookt still forward right,
Still as she fled, her eye she backward threw,
And Cupid still emongst them kindled lustfull fires.
Still did she roue at her with crafty glaunce
But yet her wound still inward freshly bled,
Of which they still the girlond bore away,
Tydings thereof, and so them still debar'd.
Did chaunce to still into her wearie spright,
But that she still did waste, and still did wayle,
But that she still did waste, and still did wayle,
With that the Prophet still awhile did stay,
Eftsoones the roaring billowes still abid,
Did feele his pulse, she knew their staied still
Yet did false Archimage her still pursew,
And of each turning still kept warie heed:
Yet he her followd still with courage keene,
But to his first poursuit him forward still doth call.
And still the foster with his long bore-speare
Yet still the bloud forth gusht in so great store,
To commun accidents still open layd,
Still as his wound did gather, and grow hole,
So still his hart woxe sore, and health decayd:
Still whenas he beheld the heauenly Mayd,
So still his Malady the more increast,
Still when her excellencies he did vew,
Yet still he wasted, as the snow congealed,
Which still increast, till she her terme had full outgone.
But still remaines in euerlasting store,
For still she feared to be ouerhent,
And fierce he still appeard, the more he did him thresh.
Sith him he saw still stronger grow through strife,
But still when him at hand she did espy,
Yet still with gentle countenaunce retained,
Are still emongst them song, that far my rymes exceed.
In their first errour, and yet still anew
But seeing still the more desir'd to see,
But he him selfe sate looking still askaunce,
Still when he mused on his late mischiefe,
Then still the smart thereof increased more,
Yet stoupt he not, but lay still in the wind,
But chose emongst the iolly Satyres still to wonne.
His nimble feet, as treading still on thorne:
That as a Snake, still lurked in his wounded mind.
Still fled he forward, looking backward still,
Still fled he forward, looking backward still,
Still ope he keepes for that occasion;
Still as she stood, she heard with grieuous throb
Though much emmou'd, but stedfast still perseuered.
Proceeding to the midst, he still did stand,
The noble Mayd, still standing all this vewd,
For still he far'd as dauncing in delight,
That in the idle aire he mou'd still here and there.
Which still he blew, and kindled busily,
And on a broken reed he still did stay
Vnder his eyebrowes looking still askaunce;
Holding a lattice still before his face,
Through which he still did peepe, as forward he did pace.
About her head, still roming here and there;
Her forward still with torture did constraine,
But still with stedfast eye and courage stout
Still in a knot, vnto her heeles downe traced,
That still are led with euery light report.
Who rolled on an heape lay still in swound,
Such is thy wont, that still when any Knight
Where lying still a while, both did forget
Still watcht on euery side, of secret foes affrayd.
She them saluting, there by them sate still,
And thousand perills which them still awate,
That still the life stood fearelesse of her foe:
Stood still a while, and his fast footing kept,
But Cambell still more strong and greater grew,
Still when as he enfeebled was, him cherisht,
Stood still amaz'd, holding his idle sweard;
Yet still that direfull stroke kept on his way,
Thereat the Champions both stood still a space,
And they like men astonisht still did stand.
Whether shall haue the Hag, or hold the Lady still.
Albee his turne were next; but stood there still,
And with vnwearied powre his party still assured.
But still the Knights of Maidenhead the better wonne.
The prize of beautie still hath ioyned beene;
Still as aduantage they espyde thereto:
His strength still more, but she still more decrewed.
His strength still more, but she still more decrewed.
And looking sterne, still ouer him did stand,
And fayned still her former angry mood,
Yet he therewith so felly still did raue,
But stood still mute, as if he had beene dum,
Yet saw her forward still to make her flight,
So tempting her still to pursue the pray,
And still from her escaping soft away:
And make me loath this life, still longing for to die.
But after them did barke, and still backbite,
Yet she him still detaines in captiue hold
Hauing a keeper still with him in place;
I neuer ioyed howre, but still with care was moued.
Yet I perseuer'd still to knocke and call,
And vnderneath, the riuer rolling still
Then th'elder, and him maystred still in all debate.
Tormented sore, could not containe it still,
For stedfast still her eyes did fixed rest,
And huge Orion, that doth tempests still portend.
Liues still: and to this feast with Neptunes seed was dight.
Swift Rhene, and Alpheus still immaculate:
Stood still by him astonisht at his lore,
And the still Darent, in whose waters cleane
His way still vnder ground, till Thamis he ouertake.
Still Vre, swift Werfe, and Oze the most of might,
Oft tossed with his stormes, which therein still remaine.
And seeming still to smile, Glauconome,
And still bemoning her vnworthy paine.
It to reueale: who still her answered, there was nought.
With which his daughter doth him still support;
For any thing wold slacke, but still vppon him hong.
But Artegall pursewd him still so neare,
Yet still he bet, and bounst vppon the dore,
But still continu'd his assault the more,
Still holding vp her suppliant hands on hye,
In th'other scale; but still it downe did slide,
He gazed still vpon that snowy mayd;
Eftsoones he stood as still as any stake,
I hold mine owne, and so will hold it still.
Yet still her blowes he bore, and her forbore,
Yet still her crueltie increased more,
And though he still retyr'd, yet nathelesse
With many idle stoups her troubling still:
Of her fierce wrath, and backward still retyre,
So much the greater still her anguish grew,
And still the more she stroue it to subdew,
The more she still augmented her owne smart,
But dread of shame my doubtfull lips doth still restraine.
Yet so, as bound to me he may continue still.
Moue Radigund? who though she still haue worne
Yet to her Dame him still she discommended,
Be well aduiz'd, that he stand stedfast still:
With which those Amazons his loue still craued,
Yet when she reckned them, still drawing neare,
And stood still mute, as one in great suspence,
But still right downe, and in her thought did hide
Now walking soft, now sitting still vpright,
Which still was wont with Artegall remaine;
And thereuppon long while stood gazing still,
With which she vsed still to tye her fone;
But th'other still pursu'd the fearefull Mayd;
Who still from him as fast away did flie,
Continu'd still his course, and by the way
He ran still on, thinking to follow fast
Who seeing him come still so fiercely on,
To Iustice, and against her still doth fight,
Kept himselfe still in his straunge armour dight.
Yet still he him did follow euerywhere,
Still when he sought t'approch vnto him ny,
Yet still the Prince pursew'd him close behind,
Where still the stronger doth the weake deuoure,
The whiles the Prince there kept the entrance still:
Who them to their posterities doe still declare.
And all his way before him still prepare.
But euen that which thou sauedst, thine still to remaine?
That stretcht it selfe, as it had long lyen still;
Whilest still she stands as stonisht and forlorne:
Yet still he striues, ne any perill spares,
For she by force is still fro me detayned,
Nathlesse the yron man did still pursew
But still the tyrant sternely at him layd,
But enuies cloud still dimmeth vertues ray.
And still among most bitter wordes they spake,
So much the more at him still did she scold,
From his right course, but still the way did hold
To find him out, yet still I forward trace.
Him long forbore, and still his spirite spar'd,
Who as he still decayd, so he encreased more.
Of his late fall, a while he rested still:
Which as it still encreast, so still increast
Which as it still encreast, so still increast
Subiect to fortunes chance, still chaunging new;
But still his passion grew more violent and strong.
Yet was he courteous still to euery wight,
Therefore there still he stood as in a stound,
Vpstaying still her selfe vppon her steede,
Yet he him still pursew'd from place to place,
But his best succour and refuge was still
But chaste him still, for all his Ladies cry;
For herbes to dresse their wounds; still seeming faine,
Who though he were still in this desert wood,
And creeping still behinde, doth him incomber,
Creeping behinde him still to haue destroyde:
Remoued is, th'effect surceaseth still.
Yet he them still so sharpely did pursew,
And wretched end, which still attendeth on her.
For cowardize doth still in villany delight.
Who flying still did ward, and warding fly away.
But when his foe he still so eger saw,
Still looking after him, that did him chace;
But still did lie as dead, and quake, and quiuer,
Where still he bathed lay in his owne bloody gore.
Her therewith yirks, and still when she complaines,
Nathelesse so sharpely still he him pursewd,
Where still he lay, ne out of swoune awooke,
Him still reuiling and afflicting sore,
